title: Handling Setbacks With Depression

content: What initially comes to mind when I think of setbacks, as it pertains to my depression and mental health, was back in the very beginning of 2020, when the antidepressant I was prescribed stopped working.
It was followed by a global pandemic and all that came with it, including a shutdown of the office where I went for one-on-one talk therapy and a shutdown of just about everywhere else. For everyone.
Fast forward to March of 2021, when my best friend was found dead in his apartment from an apparent overdose. He was 35 years old, with a baby less than a year old and a daughter not yet 17.
All of which led to me eventually relapsing and ending up at the door of a treatment center for drugs and alcohol by December.

So to say I’ve endured a few setbacks, as far as depression, treatment for it, and life as a whole is concerned, is quite the understatement – and I say that without shame, guilt, or fear. I don’t apologize for my setbacks to other people that they didn’t personally affect or harm.

content: Those who know me and love me unconditionally know and get it. They don’t require constant apologies from me for enduring and dealing with all I have, in the way I do or have . But I give apologies where they’re due and warranted because, despite my setbacks, I live with principles today.
In fact, it was because of my setbacks, I was able to propel myself forward.
My late best friend who I mentioned above had conversations before he passed about how it wasn’t the setbacks one should focus on, but the comeback or bounce back, so to speak.
I’m glad I have those kinds of conversations to reflect on because they serve me well today in enduring my own setbacks, both in depression and life.
Because setbacks are by no means a territory exclusive to those with depression, or any other mental health condition for that matter . They’re simply a part of life and being human.

content: It’s not about how many times we fall and feel like we can’t get back up, can’t get out of the bed, or can’t endure our condition or circumstances altogether. It’s about how many times we pull ourselves back up and handle our business. Whatever our business may be that day, we take care of it, even if it’s just being as kind as we possibly can to ourselves and others because there’s healing in that as well.
If we do our best every day to deal with the setbacks as they come, we are well on our way, even when it doesn’t necessarily feel as though this is the case.
If I hope for the best but prepare for the worst without expecting it on a daily basis, there’s no setback I can’t handle with, dare I say, even a bit of grace.
